Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2009 07:32PM PatMom wrote: This is just one of innumerable decisions that you will be making in the coming months.  Each choice has pros and cons...the trick is to find the combination of things that you will feel most comfortable both physically and emotionally living with in the future.  The first thing to know is if there is any evidence of activity in other areas.  For me, that there were suspicious areas in the other breast confirmed my decision to have a bilateral mastectomy.  That my breasts were lumpy, saggy, and swollen and sore at least half the month made that decision easier for me. If you have a different situation, that may affect the choices you make.  Will you be more upset about the possible loss of sensation, or of still needing to go for mammograms every 6 months?  If you choose lumpectomy, are you willing to follow through with the daily radiation treatments for weeks or will your location/health/other things make that an issue?  These are things to consider since the similar prognosis is for mastectomy vs. lumpectomy and radiation.  If you can't complete the radiation portion, there is a difference in prognosis.    With a skin sparing mastectomy, and immediate reconstruction with silicone implants, they are now smaller, firmer and more like they were before kids.  It is almost a year out from surgery for me, and feeling is returning to much of the area, although that doesn't happen for everyone.  Take your time, weigh all of your options, find surgeons (breast and plastic) whom you trust and make the decision that works best for you.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 09:45AM PatMom wrote: I put my faith in God to get me through surgery, and to help me make the right decisions about the rest of my treatment.  Radiation was not recommended for me because I had a bilateral mastectomy, and the location of the tumor meant that there were very wide margins.  I chose not to do chemo because I felt that for me, the small potential benefit was outweighed by the large potential long term risks and guaranteed side effects. I also realized that if the cancer cameback or spread despite doing advjunct chemo, I would be so far down in a pit that I might not have anything left to continue fighting.  I was not in a good place physically or emotionally when I was diagnosed.  I had just survived an extremely taxing and stressful year, and my immune system was not functioning anywhere near its normal level.    I chose to get my immune system back on track, so now I make sure I get my exercise and sleep, take vitamins and have lost a great deal of weight.  I did choose to take Tamoxifen since most of the side effects are things I can live with, and I believe that it will be effective in preventing spead/return of my highly er+ tumor.  I know that regardless of what comes in the future, I have made the right treatment decisions for me, and no matter what combination you choose, I hope that you will have that comfort as well. Pat

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2008 06:52AM PatMom wrote: Hi Renee, I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with implants, and I have no regrets.  I went to a smaller cup size, so I was able to get my silicone implants in the original surgery.  My perky new boobs were at least part of my inspiration to lose almost 50 pounds in the last 6 months, so in many ways I feel like I have my young adult body back instead of my middle aged fat and saggy one.  It did take months to really feel like "me" again, without reminders when I reached for something off a high shelf etc., but at this point I find very few restrictions on my movements, and most of them are probably the same thing I would have with any movement I don't do on a regular basis.  There are many reconstruction options, and you don't have to make that decision now if you aren't ready, you can decide to do reconstruction later. Having the mastectomy allowed me to skip radiation and all its side effects. My final pathology showed pre-cancerous growths in the 'other' breast, so for me, the bilateral was the right choice.  You need to make the choice for yourself that you will be comfortable with a year, ten years and twenty years down the road.  Pat

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2010 06:01PM PatMom wrote: I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction with implants.  I had two drains.  How many drains and how long they stay in varies widely depending on your surgeon and how quickly you heal.  I was told that it would take about a month to heal, and by the time a month had passed, I could do most things.  Vacuuming took longer, and lifting heavy objects, expecially things that had to be held out at arms length also took awhile.  I had surgery in March of 2008, and still needed someone else to lift the Thanksgiving turkey into and out of the oven.  If your current implants are placed below the muscle, you may not have as much recovery time with that.  This year lifting the turkey was no issue at all.  Bouncing up and down took quite awhile to get used to, but that may be as much because of the amount of weight moving with the implants and pulling on tender skin and muscles that had been shifted.  If you are replacing implants that your body is already used to, that may go more quickly for you.  In the meantime, I found that wearing two sports bras at a time, with one of them being tight, helped keep everything in place.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2009 02:42PM PatMom wrote: Hi Lexus, so sorry about the reason that you find yourself here, but you will find lots of help no matter what treatments you wind up doing.  A bilateral mastectomy is a relatively aggressive surgical choice for stage I.  Unless there is evidence of lymph node involvement, or a problem getting good margins, you should be able to avoid radiation which is standard with lumpectomy but is only used in specific situations after mastectomy. There are so many things like lymph node and vascular involvement and margins that you won't know about for sure until after you get the final pathology after surgery.  You want to make treatment decisions based on the full picture, including your age and other health issues, not just the preliminary results from the biopsy.  My tumor was highly hormone receptor positive, and HER positive.  There was no node involvement or vascular involvement.  I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate reconstruction.  I have also lost a significant amount of weight since diagnosis which lowers the volume of hormone that my body stores.  I decided that for me, my best shot at keeping this from coming back or spreading elsewhere in my body was to start taking Tamoxifen as soon as possible.  I chose not to do chemotherapy and Herceptin since that would have delayed my ability to start taking Tamoxifen, and I have other health issues that put me at increased risk of significant long term damage from the chemotherapy.  If this does come back, I still have Herceptin available in my arsenal.  I know that I made the right decision for me, but I also realize that the decision that I made is not the right one for everyone. If your tumor is not strongly hormone receptor positive, you may not get the same benefit from Tamoxifen, and especially in that case, you might want to consider the chemo and Herceptin.  There are also a variety of chemo agents with varying side effects (and other drugs to counteract those side effects) that can be used with Herceptin, so you and your oncologist may be able to find a combination that you feel confident about. There is a test called the Oncotype DX that uses material from your tumor, and can tell you how much benefit you personally are likely to get from the various treatment combinations, and can help you make those treatment decisions. You need to gather as much information as possible, especially about the specific combination of treatments being proposed for you and their actual benefit, not just their relative benefit, before you make any decisions because I agree with NanA that you need to be sure that you can live with your decision without regrets.

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 11:22AM PatMom wrote: It has nothing at all to do with whether or not someone has been diagnosed with cancer, or what stage it is.  Everyone deserves to be treated with respect.  Nobody should feel that they have to tolerate abuse (physical or emotional).  We are all imperfect humans and get tired and frustrated, and make mistakes, but the occasional outburst is different than a pattern of abuse.  If it is happening on a regular basis, please, please get help.  We all deserve to live, not just survive, and you cease to live and begin to simply exist when you are abused.  No one at any stage deserves that.  Witnessing abuse does nothing to help our children, and seeing it tolerated sets them up to tolerate abuse that is directed at them in the future.  If you are feeling abused and can't muster up the strength to do something about it for yourself, then find the strength to do it for your children and their future.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2010 12:53AM PatMom wrote: Other factors to consider in the chemo decision are whether you have any other conditions that could make chemo more likely to result in long term or permanent side effects for you.  Things like diabetes, asthma, any cardiac problems, nerve damage, or allergies could lead to life changing side effects.  What is your life like?  Chemo damages your immune system while you are in treatment, so if your normal life exposes you to lots of germs, that could be an issue for you.  It also carries a small risk of actually causing other illnesses including leukemia. You need to figure out for yourself and your unique situation if your potential benefits against the risk of distant cancer spread is greater than your risk of injury or illness from the chemo itself.  Of the two systemic treatments, hormone treatment is considered the more important and more effective.  If you even suspect that you would have trouble sticking with the 5 years of hormone treatment after chemo, do the hormone treatment.

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2009 07:11PM PatMom wrote: The Bottle O Tamoxifen thread has 147 pages of posts from women who are either on Tamoxifen, were on Tamoxifen, or are about to start taking Tamoxifen.  In those pages, you will probably come across every possible side effect that people have experienced.  That is a great place to check to see if you think you could live with the possible side effects (remember that nobody gets all of the possible side effects). The only significant hair issues I've seen there are related to the chemo that many of the women had before they started on Tamoxifen.  Ask your pharmacist for a printout of the information that is included with a Tamoxifen prescription.  Your doctor will give you general information about benefits, risks and side effects, but a pharmacist is a much better source for specifics on this drug.  The benefits are much clearer for women who have already been diagnosed with ER+ breast cancer than for someone taking it to prevent an initial diagnosis.  The side effects and risks are the same.  You need to decide if your current risk of breast cancer is great enough to justify taking a medication for 5 years to prevent it.  I wish you confidence in your decison, and that you never get the breast cancer diagnosis that you are trying to avoid.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 05:59AM PatMom wrote: You are coming up on the one year anniversary of diagnosis, and that is frequently a trigger for the inertia and depressed feelings that you seem to be experiencing.  Toss in that "active" treatment is wrapping up, and you have a recipe for exactly what you are going through.  There are very limited options for anti-depressants that don't interfere with the Tamoxifen, so all of your other medical personnel deferring to your oncologist on that may be more helpful than it seems to you right now.  That is probably also why your MO's office is looking to move up the appointment rather than have the doctor call in a prescription without actually seeing you.  What you are experiencing is real, it is normal, and it is no fun at all.  I got through it by having too much to do in a day, but that was not fun either.  Exercise helps.  Having specific things that need to be done at specific times (like participating in a class) helps, but the only real "cure" is time.  Being grateful to be alive and healthy is good, but not required.  Feeling guilty because you don't feel enthusiastic enough about being alive and healthy is not as helpful.  I hope that you can get through this quickly.

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2010 10:49PM PatMom wrote: Beesie is right, after MX, any local recurrence is right against the skin, and is easy to find because it is not hiding in the breast tissue.  Most of the lumps and bumps etc. will turn out to be fat, or insect bites, or scar tissue.  I've had a couple of areas that were worrisome, they were biopsied with a fine needle, and turned out to be fat necrosis.  There is always the possibility that a tiny bit of breast tissue remains even in a BMX, but if something is lurking, it tends to be found very easily very early.  With pure DCIS, there is no chance of distant recurrence or mets.  If there is any invasive component, then there is some small chance, but Winterstorm, with your small, low grade tumor, your chances of living a long life and never dealing with breast cancer again are fantastic.  Right now, you don't trust your body because it betrayed you and got cancer.  You dealt with that cancer, and time will help you heal and start to trust your body again.  It takes time, give yourself that time.

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2008 11:17AM PatMom wrote: I don't know, but I know that I was under extreme and constant stress, including sleep deprivation, a total lack of energy and privacy, and high noise levels for a year before I was diagnosed, and that my immune system was not functioning the way it normally does.  Did that cause the cancer?  Probably not.  Did that allow the cancer to get a hold that would normally have been knocked out by my immune system?  Possibly.  I chose to go in the direction of lowering my stress level, boosting my immune system, getting exercise daily and allowing myself to get a full night's sleep every night. Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2009 01:58PM PatMom wrote: There are a huge number of things to take into account when developing a treatment plan.  They include the patient's age, general health, other risk factors, ER, PR,  & Her status, how wide the surgical margins were, your location...there is a difference in the options that are realistic in a major city vs. an outlying area of a third world nation.  After all those and many other factors are considered, the bottom line comes down to the patient's choice.  If the patient feels the need for a specific treatment to feel safe from the cancer returning, then serious consideration should be given to that.  On the other hand, if the patient is opposed to a specific treatment, pushing that treatment onto that patient against her will would be unethical at best. We are not doctors, and no legitimate trained medical specialist would present an opinion based on so little information.  What does your future Mother-in-Law want to do?  That is where the discussion should start.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2010 04:45AM PatMom wrote: This thread is on the Stage I and II forum.  The vast majority of women who are diagnosed at those stages are cured by surgery.  The problem is that medical science at this moment has no way of telling which ones.  Breast cancer still affects 1 in 8 women, and typically is more common the older women get, so just because someone has breast cancer at a younger age and is cured, there is no guarantee that they won't develop the same type of cancer again, especially if they continue to be exposed to the same environmental and lifestyle triggers.  There are some things we know can help prevent cancer, especially breast cancer, but they don't get much press.  Diet, exercise, vitamin D, and alcohol consumption are all parts of the puzzle, but they aren't glamorous, and don't hold a large profit motive. Some diseases like measles confer immunity from future illness, cancer does not.  That doesn't mean it wasn't cured.  If you get pneumonia, are cured, and get it again twenty years later, no one thinks that you have had pneumonia for twenty years, although there may be a suspicion that you are more susceptible to it than the general population.  Stage IV cancer is different.  There is treatment, but no cure.  People with stage IV can achieve remission, sometimes for a long period of time, but they are not cured.  Yet.  That is what we need to work to change in our lifetimes.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2008 01:16PM PatMom wrote: If you are young enough to enlist in the military, the chances are very good that the lump you are feeling is benign, but.... the only way to know for sure is to get it checked out.  You should be doing that for yourself regardless of your potential military career.  You might want to start by contacting your local health department, or local branch of the American Cancer Society to see what services are available in your area to someone in your situation at low or no cost.  If you try to enlist without disclosing the lump, you could have other major issues with the military, and you don't need that.  Ask your recruiter what happens if the physical turns up an issue... the different branches have different thresholds, and that may affect the answer.  Also, your recruiter may be more likely to find a way to help you get through the physical if he/she is having issues making his/her quota of recruits for the month, so even if you don't "qualify" instantly after getting the all clear on the lump, a couple of months time, or a different recruiter might give you a different answer.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 05:48PM PatMom wrote: So sorry that your friend is facing such a life altering decision.  Something to take into consideration is if she has any other health issues or family history of health issues.  Many chemo combinations can cause or exacerbate cardiac problems, and neuropathy, and can cause issues with autoimmune disorders.  Steroids are also commonly given to help deal with some of chemo's side effects, and there are many health issues that can be a bad mix with steroids.  Just like the benefits of chemo vary depending on the specifics of a person's diagnosis, the risks of chemo are affected by the specifics of pre-existing health conditions and family history. I hope that she finds peace for decades to come with whichever treatment decisions she makes.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 11:30AM PatMom wrote: Hearing the words "It's cancer" is terrifying and life changing.  Stage may make a difference in the treatment options, but so do other factors like age, and general health, and specific health issues.  We can't read minds, and sometimes we don't take the time to read someone's previous posts and/or profile to find out what other factors may be at play in someone's decisions before commenting.  We all have difficult days, no matter what stage we are at.  We get scary news, we have other things happen in our lives (yes, there is life beyond cancer), we find out that we or someone we care about has had progression.  We also get good news, and want to share that with our sisters because that might be just the ray of hope that someone else needs at this moment. The larger the community, the greater the opportunity to hurt or offend someone.  This unfortunately is a huge community.  That means a great amount of support, but also the potential to offend.  If someone posts something that bothers you, let them know gently in a PM, the way you would take a friend aside if they said something hurtful.  Or ignore it, or put them on ignore status, or roll your eyes and move on. This is similar to cooking with steam.  If you don't vent it at all, you can have an explosion.  If you don't vent carefully, you can get burned, and if you take the lid off totally, you lose the power of the steam. Think before you hit submit, vent carefully, and be forgiving of someone who vents in the heat of the moment.

Posts.Content: PatMom wrote: At this point, there should be years of data on the effectiveness of adjuvant chemo.  I have seen a few very small studies comparing different combinations of chemo agents, but I haven't found a comprehensive study of the impact of adjuvant chemo on the the development of metastasis.  If the adjuvant chemo is as effective as we are all being led to believe, then there should have been a substantial reduction in the percentage of women diagnosed at an early stage who then go on to develop stage IV cancer.  Has there been?  If there is not a significant reduction in metastasis, then why are so many women being subjected to the side effects of chemo?  If there is a significant reduction, where are the studies touting it? Until the time when someone comes up with a definitive "cure", we each have to cobble together what we believe will be the most effective treatment that we can live with, not merely survive. Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 08:29PM PatMom wrote: Are you sure that it is the same bump from a couple of weeks ago, or could it be a new one in the same/similar location?  It looks like it could be some kind of bug bite, but that should have cleared up in a couple of weeks, not gotten larger and angrier looking.  Spiders and redbugs AKA chiggers both come to mind, but even Austin is probably too cold for chiggers this time of year.  You say that it itches.  Has it itched the entire time, or just since yesterday?  That may help you figure out whether it is the same injury or a new one in the same location.  A new injury in the same location is much less worrisome than an injury that has not only not healed over a period of time, but has actually gotten worse. You complain of being tired, and sleeping most of the day today.  If there isn't another explaination for your tiredness, that is a red flag that you should be getting it dealt with by a medical professional. Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2009 10:46AM PatMom wrote: Congratulations!  Do you have approval from the baby's pediatrician to breastfeed?  Keeping that precious new baby safe is the first priority. As far as your question goes, your best bet is to have a consultation with a lymphedema specialist (or physical therapist who specializes in lymphedema).  He/she will be able to evaluate your specific situation including the pathways that your fluid follows, and the severity of your involvement, and be able to teach you the manual draining techniques which will help you whether or not you decide to use that breast to breast feed.  Depending on the exact location of your involvement, the action of breastfeeding may serve to help the lymph fluid to drain, and/or you may be able to time your manual draining to occur after you finish a nursing session when the new baby is likely to be sleeping, or at least content. Wishing you all the best on your new adventure.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2008 01:16AM PatMom wrote: Hi Danielle, You are still very young to have to worry about this, and it is definitely not an emergency situation.  The solution you are looking at is drastic...effective, but drastic, and not one that you can reverse later.  It is great that your fiance is being supportive, and knowing your risks, you may want to get genetic counseling, and maybe to think about starting your family sooner rather than later, but surgery can probably wait a few years till after you have any child(ren) that you are planning. How old were your mother, aunts, grandmother when they were diagnosed?  That should give you a basic idea of timing for yourself.  You definitely want to make your decision at least a few years (preferably 10) before the youngest age at which a close relative was diagnosed.  I am in a very different situation than you are.  I had invasive cancer in one breast, and pre-cancerous changes in the other.  My children are adults, and I was long done with breastfeeding.  I had a bilateral mastectomy with immediate implants in March.  I am very happy with the results, but I still get twinges when I move too quickly and stretch too far.  I am also aware that not everyone has the kind of results that I do.  There is a time for everything.   The time to worry about the future is still in the future.  I am one who is hopeful that by the time you (and my daughter and my niece) are old enough to need to worry about developing breast cancer there will be a cure, or even better, something easy and effective (and less drastic than mastectomy) to prevent it.  If not, you can always make the decision to have the surgery when it is right for you.  For now, appreciate the fact that your suspicious lump was benign, enjoy your wedding, and start your new life.

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2008 05:18PM PatMom wrote: Kim, This is what I think you are saying: You have cysts.  The mammogram hurts.  You don't want to do the followup mammogram, and you are looking for someone to say that you don't need to do anything and you'll be just fine.  That's not going to happen. This is a site where the vast majority of posters have been diagnosed with Breast Cancer.  You're not likely to find anyone who tells you that you can ignore the doctors' concerns and go on your merry way. That being said, you mention that you had a request for an ultrasound.  Why don't you make the appointment for the ultrasound.  That test shouldn't hurt like the mammogram, and should help the doctors sort out whether there are any solid areas among those cysts.  Cysts and lumps look pretty similar in a mammogram, but are frequently easily distinguishable on an ultrasound.  The ultrasound may give them the additional information they need to make sure you get all the care you need.  If the ultrasound shows something that needs to be dealt with you can deal with it, and if it doesn't, you can have peace of mind.  See, He did send you a boat, now you need to get in and start rowing.

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 06:48PM PatMom wrote: Tamoxifen acts like a hormone in your system, and hormones raise blood sugar levels.  That is one reason why they may tend to cycle higher between ovulation and the start of your period and lower through the rest of your menstrual cycle.  If you are past menopause, you may be put on an Aromatase Inhibitor instead of Tamoxifen and they block the production of hormones, so that might help you lower those levels.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2008 10:09AM PatMom wrote: My husband was able to take 6 weeks of family leave time to take care of me and the household after my bilateral mastectomy.  After about a month, I was more than ready for him to go back to work, and started really bugging him to get some major projects done around the house.  You certainly need and deserve more than a week to heal before you go back.  At a week, I still had drains in place, and the risk of infection alone should keep you from work at least until they are out! Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2008 12:57PM PatMom wrote: Hi Lightworker, I hope that everything turns out to be benign, but in the meantime, I'm glad that you've found this extremely supportive community. You will want to keep a close watch on your blood glucose levels as you go through the process of diagnosis and treatment.  Everything from stress, to the biopsy itself, to antibiotics and pain relievers, to chemo and the steriods given with chemo, and hormonal treatments that Julie mentioned as well as Tamoxifen can cause those levels to fluctuate, so you should have a plan of action for monitoring and treating those fluctuations in place with the physician who deals with your diabetes as you move through the next months.  It helps that you are starting off with your levels in a stable situation since keeping them close to "normal" will help with all of the healing processes. Right now, you need to find a good breast surgeon, and a good oncologist.  Once you find one of them, they will help you build your team.  It may help to deal with a facility that specializes in breast health or cancer treatment.  It will probably take a few weeks to schedule an appointment, and get to the point of biopsy.  The radiologist was probably just trying to ease your mind that the wait to get to that point should not make any difference in the outcome, rather than encouraging you to wait before making the appointment.  The diabetes increases your risk of cardiac issues and neuropathy among many others.  If you find that it is cancer, the diabetes may impact the types of treatment you can receive since your risk of some side effects will be higher than the "typical" patient, changing the risk/benefit ratio for you.  Like so much of life, take this one step at a time and keep moving forward.  Hoping for B9 results, Pat

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 11:58AM PatMom wrote: Some of the posts on this thread imply that women who do adjuvant chemo won't go on to develop a recurrence, or a spread to stage IV.  That is not true.  There are many women on these boards who did the whole chemo experience who are now posting on the stage IV threads.  Some of them didn't even make it through the whole course of chemo or chemo and herceptin before they were diagnosed again. There are no guarantees in breast cancer treatment, and anyone who tells you that there are is lying to you. Do your research, and then research some more, especially look at the long term and short term side effects of every specific drug or treatment being proposed for you.  Realize that some chemotherapies can actually increase your risk of developing other cancers.  Take into consideration any other conditions that may be pre-existing or that you may be at risk for due to environment or family history that may be triggered by or exacerbated by a particular treatment or it's side effects.  Then honor yourself, make the decision that lets you sleep at night, and don't let anyone bully you into or out of a treatment that you believe is the right course for you.

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2009 10:04AM PatMom wrote: Hi Judy, My diabetes diagnosis was very new when I went in for surgery last March, in fact I was in the pre-op area, and they had to switch out the glucose IV for "ringers?" when they ran a blood glucose test on me after the pre-op testing came out high, and that test was high too. I had no trouble healing from the surgery, no trouble with infection, and I had immediate reconstruction with silicone implants, no expanders since the implants are smaller than what I started with, and I had a skin sparing mastectomy.   The drains were the worst part of the experience...they didn't hurt at first, but as time went on they pulled at the stich holding them in place with every breath.   Keep your arms still, and you won't have as much drainage, so they will come out faster, hopefully before they start hurting.   I've lost over 50 lbs in the past year, and I feel great.  My last A1-C was 6.0, but I take metformin, watch my diet, and exercise.  My fasting blood glucose readings still aren't where I want them to be (where a person without diabetes is), but in general, I don't get the huge swings of highs and lows.  I found that when I started the Tamoxifen, my readings went up about 20 points consistently, and that the dose of metformin that I'm on brings them down about 20 points consistently, so I'm hoping that when I go off the Tamoxifen, I'll be able to stop the metformin too.  Let us know how your surgery goes....we'll be praying for you.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 04:47PM PatMom wrote: I'm so sorry to hear what a difficult time your mother is having with treatment.  I know that it is scary to be an adult kid and watch your parent struggle.  I've been on both sides of the equation, and I firmly believe that in many ways, it is easier to be the patient than to be the worried loved one.  Cancer staging and treatment can be an art as much as a science since there are so many variables involved.  Hopefully the radiation will be more effective for her than that chemo was.  There are a number of different chemo regimens, so a different combo may work better for her. Lymph nodes are removed to help in staging, not as treatment.  Recent studies seem to indicate that it makes no difference in treatment outcome whether they stay or are removed.     Chances are that your mom knows at least a bit more about her situation than she is sharing with you.  Even when our kids are adults, we try to shield them as much as possible.  She also may need time to recover from the surgery itself, and process the situation of the chemo not getting all of the cancer before she is able to share specifics with you.  I needed to know the whole situation and deal with it myself before I was ready to tell my adult kids. I learned that my daughter's imagination of  what was going on was far worse than the reality, so now I try to keep her in the loop as much as possible without going into overwhleming detail, but sometimes we don't know the whole story yet, so we really can't share.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 12:34PM PatMom wrote: In the original post you ask "what if I don't do chemo and the cancer comes back?" Chemo is not a guarantee that the cancer won't come back.  Too many women on this board did adjuvant chemo and still were diagnosed with another cancer, or spread of the original cancer.  Another important question to ask yourself is how you would feel if you did the chemo and the cancer still came back, especially if you were left with long term or permanent side effects from the chemo.  The Oncotype test uses material taken from your tumor, which I am guessing from the way your post is worded, was removed before the hysterectomy.  Does the lower hormone level as a result of that surgery change what your score would have been had the hysterectomy occured enough months before the lumpectomy to lower your body's estrogen levels?  It might be worth contacting Genomic Health for the answer to that question. It is a huge decision with potentially life changing consequences, you need to make the decision that is right for you, not the one that anyone else wants you to make.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2011 12:46PM PatMom wrote: The 5% risk of a new cancer comes from LtotheK's post on the last page.  The 10% was to err on the side of caution.  Most studies have shown chemo to only help 2% to 3% of women given it.  That may have changed as more women opt out of chemo due to low oncotype scores.  Remember, only 20% to 30% were ever going to develop metastic disease in the first place.  If you cut that figure in half with chemo (and that is being generous toward chemo since it doesn't include the decrease due to hormonal treatments) the figure goes to 10% to 15% at the most who might get an actual benefit from chemo.

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2008 11:10AM PatMom wrote: I did have some hospital visitors...a friend who is a survivor, and part of my support system stopped by the next day for a few minutes on her lunch break, another who is a nurse brought my kids for a short visit so my husband wouldn't have to leave to go home and get them and then leave again to bring them back home.  I did feel up to seeing people.  I especially knew that it was important that my kids see that I was really alright for their peace of mind, and knowing that they were reassured helped me too.  Seeing people face to face was actually easier than phone calls.  Holding the phone up to my ear for more than a minute or two hurt my arm and pulled. You know which visitors will help you get better quicker, and which will not.  It's good to have a husband (or other person who can be gentle but firm) to serve as the gatekeeper for visitors and phone calls both in the hospital, and once you get home as well.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 05:43PM PatMom wrote: You just did when you posted here. It is overwhelmingly likely that the hip pain is a result of the broken leg.  If the rod isn't exactly the perfect fit it will cause pressure on the rest of the leg, and favoring the one leg puts more of a stress on the other leg and the joints associated with it.  It's not like you have a sedentary job either, so that may be part of the equation. The surgical recommendations to deal with the BRCA status are just that.  You have had that mutation all along, and it has not suddenly become an emergency situation just because you are aware of it now.  Trust your instincts about how to proceed.  They have been accurate in the past.  You will know what to do, it's just a matter of getting your head into the right frame of mind to deal with it.  We all know that you can get through whatever life throws at you.  .   Enjoy your vacation.  Put cancer out of your mind and life as much as possible until you get back.  Once you get back, settle in, and everyone has figured out the normal routine for the coming school year, start dealing with the doctors again.

Since this is work related, you should be able to enlist the help of your co-workers to practice throwing the ball far enough to get to home plate and the catcher's mitt.  Concentrate on the action, not on who is around you.
